definition.conceptual: The electron-to-Planck mass ratio is a fundamental dimensionless number that quantifies how much lighter the electron is compared to the Planck mass. This tiny ratio is central to the hierarchy problem in particle physics and reflects the vast separation between electroweak and gravitational energy scales.

alternative_forms.description: Square root of gravitational coupling constant
In terms of electron gravitational self-energy

value.interpretation: The Planck mass is about 2.4×10²² times heavier than the electron

hierarchy_problem.description: The extreme smallness of m_e/m_P is the essence of the hierarchy problem. Why is the electroweak scale (characterized by m_e and v_EW) so much smaller than the Planck scale?
hierarchy_problem.magnitude_gap: 23 orders of magnitude separate the electron mass from the Planck mass
hierarchy_problem.naturalness: From a 'natural' perspective in quantum field theory, one would expect all masses to be near the Planck scale unless protected by symmetries
proposed_solutions: Supersymmetry (SUSY) - protects Higgs mass from quantum corrections
Extra dimensions - dilutes gravity making it appear weak
Anthropic selection - small m_e/m_P needed for complex structures
Relaxion mechanism - dynamical selection of small electroweak scale

gravitational_coupling.interpretation: The gravitational force between two electrons is about 10⁴⁵ times weaker than the electromagnetic force

atomic_structure.consequence: Because m_e << m_P, atomic physics is completely described by QED and quantum mechanics, with no gravitational corrections needed
atomic_structure.gravitational_corrections: Gravitational effects on atomic spectra are suppressed by (m_e/m_P)² ~ 10⁻⁴⁵

quantum_gravity.relevance: Electron remains point-like down to scales of order ℓ_P × (m_e/m_P) ~ 10⁻⁵⁸ m
quantum_gravity.no_electron_black_holes: Electron Schwarzschild radius r_s = 2Gm_e/c² ~ 10⁻⁵⁷ m is far below Planck length

comparison_with_other_particles.observation: All known particles have mass ratios between 10⁻²⁴ (neutrinos) and 10⁻¹⁷ (top quark), leaving an enormous desert between electroweak and Planck scales

cosmological_implications.nucleosynthesis: The small m_e/m_P ratio is essential for Big Bang nucleosynthesis - electrons must be light enough for atoms to form
cosmological_implications.stellar_structure: Stars can exist because gravity (proportional to m_P) and electromagnetism (dependent on m_e) balance at macroscopic scales
cosmological_implications.anthropic: If m_e/m_P were much different, complex chemistry and life would be impossible

dimensional_analysis.characteristic_role: Measures the hierarchy between electroweak and gravitational scales

primary_sources.title: CODATA Recommended Values of the Fundamental Physical Constants

primary_sources.author: Peskin & Schroeder
primary_sources.title: An Introduction to Quantum Field Theory

common_misconceptions.misconception: The small ratio is just a numerical coincidence
common_misconceptions.correction: The extreme smallness of m_e/m_P is considered one of the deepest puzzles in physics, central to the hierarchy problem.

teaching_tips: Use logarithmic scales to visualize the 23 orders of magnitude
Connect to everyday experience: gravity is weak because m_e/m_P is tiny
Discuss how this ratio affects everything from atomic structure to stellar lifetimes
pedagogical_notes.key_insight: The fact that electrons (and all known particles) are so much lighter than the Planck mass is the fundamental reason we can study physics at low energies without worrying about quantum gravity.
